page.title: 14Social Changes in Cumnor
page.content: The Cumnor Hill{By-pass,}built in 1974 at a cost of over Â£4million trig- gered changes in the village. A oneway traffic system and a big reduction in through traffic have reduced trade for the butcher and caused the closure of one general store. However, business at Cumnor Hotel has increased partly because of the improved environment but also because of a shortage of Bed and Breakfast accommodation in rural areas for foreign tourists. Visitors from Brazil, Australia, USA, Ireland and Britain now use the hotel. The 72 new Glebelands houses, though criticised by some villagers concerned about the character of Cumnor, will provide homes on land of poor agricultural value for newlyweds and elderly folk.The remaining general store may not be able to cope with increased demand from newcomers.
